entries.meaning: (countable, uncountable) Power, strength, force or influence held by a person or group.
examples: "Since every nation considers itself right, peace lies in balancing the military mights of the possible rivals."
He pushed with all his might, but still it would not move.

description: From Old English meahte and mihte, from magan, whence English may.

verbs.description: might (third-person singular simple present might, no present participle, simple past might, no past participle)

entries.meaning: (auxiliary) Used to indicate conditional or possible actions.
examples: I might go to the party, but I haven't decided yet.

entries.meaning: (auxiliary) simple past tense of may Used to indicate permission in past tense.
examples: He asked me if he might go to the party, but I haven't decided yet.

entries.meaning: (auxiliary) simple past tense of may Used to indicate possibility in past tense.
examples: I thought that I might go the next day.

entries.meaning: Used to indicate a desired past action that was not done.
examples: Hey man, you might have warned me about the thunderstorm.
I might be in a wheelchair, but I still want to be treated as a lady.

entries.meaning: (auxiliary) Used in polite requests for permission
examples: Might I take the last biscuit?

entries.meaning: (auxiliary, UK, meiosis) Used to express certainty.
examples: Yeah, I think we might need something a bit sturdier.
